repo.name: selinux
repo.description: This is the upstream repository for the Security Enhanced Linux (SELinux) userland libraries and tools. The software provided by this project complements the SELinux features integrated into the Linux kernel and is used by Linux distributions. All bugs and patches should be submitted to selinux@vger.kernel.org

readme.summary: The README describes the overall SELinux project well but fails to explain what libsepol specifically does or how to use it, making it unsuitable for users looking for libsepol documentation.
readme.top_issue: Package name is libsepol but README is for entire SELinux Userspace project with no specific libsepol documentation, usage examples, or API guidance

injection_risks.description: The function send_request uses user-controlled data (data1 and data2) to construct a message for the setransd socket. Although it checks for NULL pointers, it does not validate or sanitize the input strings, which could potentially lead to buffer overflow vulnerabilities.

The function receive_response uses user-controlled data (function) to construct a message for the setransd socket. Although it checks for invalid file descriptors, it does not validate or sanitize the input function value, which could potentially lead to unexpected behavior.

critical_findings: Potential buffer overflow vulnerabilities in the send_request and receive_response functions.
Lack of input validation and sanitization in multiple functions.
security.summary: The code has some security concerns, including potential injection risks and lack of input validation, but overall it appears to be well-structured and follows good security practices.

common_complaints: SWIG binding bugs and missing wrappers for Python API
Lack of support for modern system architectures (stateless systems, systemd-user, sysext)
sentiment.summary: libsepol shows signs of maintenance neglect with multiple unresponded technical issues spanning memory safety, build systems, and modern Linux integration, combined with zero comments on recent bug reports indicating low community engagement.

red_flags: Lack of clear instructions for new contributors
communication.summary: Responses are generally adequate but could be more welcoming and less repetitive.

concerns: No commits in past 6 months despite last commit being recent (2026-01-10)
Zero active contributors in past 6 months
No merged pull requests in past 6 months
No closed issues in past 6 months
High number of open issues (118) with no activity
positive_signals: Recent commit timestamp suggests repository exists and is accessible
maintenance.summary: libsepol is stale with no maintenance activity in the past 6 months despite an accumulation of 118 open issues and no developer engagement.

governance.summary: The project lacks a succession plan and contributor ladder, which increases the risk of losing critical knowledge if key contributors leave.

project_metrics.description: This is the upstream repository for the Security Enhanced Linux (SELinux) userland libraries and tools. The software provided by this project complements the SELinux features integrated into the Linux kernel and is used by Linux distributions. All bugs and patches should be submitted to selinux@vger.kernel.org

analysis_summary.doc_summary: The documentation is comprehensive but lacks a clear quick start guide and troubleshooting section.
concerns: Low merged PRs in the past six months
Docs: Lack of a concise quick start example to help new users get started with the package.
Community: Missing SWIG wrapper for functions
Communication: Lack of clear instructions for new contributors
Governance: High bus factor risk identified

highlights: Recent commits in the last month
